Name: Abacus
NOTES: A tool to do calculations.

Name: Acid (Vial)
NOTES: As an action, you can splash the contents of this vial onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw the vial up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the acid as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 2d6 acid damage.

Name: Alchemist's fire (flask)
NOTES: This sticky, adhesive fluid ignites when exposed to air. As an action, you can throw this flask up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a creature or object, treating the alchemist's fire as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target takes 1d4 fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature can end this damage by using its action to make a DC 10 Dexterity check to extinguish the flames.

Name: Amulet - Holy Symbol
NOTES: A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. Appendix B lists the symbols commonly associated with many gods in the multiverse. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.

Name: Antitoxion (vial)
NOTES: A creature that drinks this vial of liquid gains advantage on saving throws against poison for 1 hour. It confers no benefit to undead or constructs.

Name: Arrow
NOTES: Needed to use a Bow.

Name: Arrows (20)
NOTES: Bundle of Arrows.

Name: Backpack
NOTES: 1 cubic foot/30 pounds of gear

Name: Ball bearing
NOTES: As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level area 10 feet square. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.

Name: Ball bearings (1000)
NOTES: As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level area 10 feet square. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.

Name: Barrel
NOTES: 40 gallons liquid, 4 cubic feet solid

Name: Basic Poison (vial)
NOTES: You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or take 1d4 poison damage. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.

Name: Basket
NOTES: 2 cubic feet/40 pounds of gear

Name: Bedroll
NOTES: Sleeping bag used typically while traveling.

Name: Bell
NOTES: Small bell. Can be made of most metals.

Name: Blanket
NOTES: A Piece of fabric that can be used to keep warm.

Name: Block and tackle
NOTES: A set of pulleys with a cable threaded through them and a hook to attach to objects, a block and tackle allows you to hoist up to four times the weight you can normally lift.

Name: Blowgun needle
NOTES: Needed to use a Blowgun.

Name: Blowgun needles (50)
NOTES: Pack of Needles.

Name: Book
NOTES: A book might contain poetry, historical accounts, information pertaining to a particular field of lore, diagrams and notes on gnomish contraptions, or just about anything else that can be represented using text or pictures. A book of spells is a spellbook (described later in this section).

Name: Bottle, glass
NOTES: 1 1/2 pints liquid

Name: Bucket
NOTES: 3 gallons liquid, 1/2 cubic foot solid

Name: Burglar's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a bag of 1,000 ball bearings, 10 feet of string, a bell, 5 candles, a crowbar, a hammer, 10 pitons, a hooded lantern, 2 flasks of oil, 5 days rations, a tinderbox, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.

Name: Caltrop
NOTES: As an action, you can spread a single bag of caltrops to cover a 5-foot-square area. Any creature that enters the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or stop moving and take 1 piercing damage. Until the creature regains at least 1 hit point, its walking speed is reduced by 10 feet. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.

Name: Caltrops (20)
NOTES: As an action, you can spread a single bag of caltrops to cover a 5-foot-square area. Any creature that enters the area must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or stop moving and take 1 piercing damage. Until the creature regains at least 1 hit point, its walking speed is reduced by 10 feet. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the saving throw.

Name: Candle
NOTES: For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

Name: Case - crossbow bolt
NOTES: This wooden case can hold up to twenty crossbow bolts.

Name: Case - map or scroll
NOTES: This cylindrical leather case can hold up to ten rolled-up sheets of paper or five rolled-up sheets of parchment.

Name: Chain (1 foot)
NOTES: A chain has 10 hit points. It can be burst with a successful DC 20 Strength check.

Name: Chain (10 feet)
NOTES: A chain has 10 hit points. It can be burst with a successful DC 20 Strength check.

Name: Chalk
NOTES: Can be used to write on surfaces

Name: Chest
NOTES: 12 cubic feet/300 pounds of gear

Name: Climber's Kit
NOTES: A climber's kit includes special pitons, boot tips, gloves, and a harness. You can use the climber's kit as an action to anchor yourself; when you do, you can't fall more than 25 feet from the point where you anchored yourself, and you can't climb more than 25 feet away from that point without undoing the anchor.

Name: Common Clothes
NOTES: Everyday clothes

Name: Component Pouch
NOTES: A component pouch is a small, watertight leather belt pouch that has compartments to hold all the material components and other special items you need to cast your spells, except for those components that have a specific cost (as indicated in a spell's description).

Name: Costume Clothes
NOTES: Clothes that can be used when wanting to wear a costume.

Name: Crossbow bolt
NOTES: Needed to use a Crossbow.

Name: Crossbow bolts (20)
NOTES: Bundle of Bolts

Name: Crowbar
NOTES: Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

Name: Crystal - Arcane Focus
NOTES: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Diplomat's Pack
NOTES: Includes a chest, 2 cases for maps and scrolls, a set of fine clothes, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, a lamp, 2 flasks of oil, 5 sheets of paper, a vial of perfume, sealing wax, and soap.

Name: Dungeoneer's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a crowbar, a hammer, 10 pitons, 10 torches, a tinderbox, 10 days of rations, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.

Name: Emblem - Holy Symbol
NOTES: A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. Appendix B lists the symbols commonly associated with many gods in the multiverse. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.

Name: Entertainer's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a bedroll, 2 costumes, 5 candles, 5 days of rations, a waterskin, and a disguise kit.

Name: Explorer's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a bedroll, a mess kit, a tinderbox, 10 torches, 10 days of rations, and a waterskin. The pack also has 50 feet of hempen rope strapped to the side of it.

Name: Fine Clothes
NOTES: Very fine clothes. You can look very fancy in these.

Name: Fishing Tackle
NOTES: This kit includes a wooden rod, silken line, corkwood bobbers, steel hooks, lead sinkers, velvet lures, and narrow netting.

Name: Flask
NOTES: 1 pint liquid

Name: Grappling Hook
NOTES: A hook that can be hitched into a suface.

Name: Hammer
NOTES: A standard hammer.

Name: Hammer - Sledge
NOTES: Very Large standard hammer.

Name: Healer's kit
NOTES: This kit is a leather pouch containing bandages, salves, and splints. The kit has ten uses. As an action, you can expend one use of the kit to stabilize a creature that has 0 hit points, without needing to make a Wisdom (Medicine) check.

Name: Hempen Rope (1 foot)
NOTES: Rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Hempen Rope (50 feet)
NOTES: Rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Holy Water (flask)
NOTES: As an action, you can splash the contents of this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. In either case, make a ranged attack against a target creature, treating the holy water as an improvised weapon. If the target is a fiend or undead, it takes 2d6 radiant damage. A cleric or paladin may create holy water by performing a special ritual. The ritual takes 1 hour to perform, uses 25 gp worth of powdered silver, and requires the caster to expend a 1st-level spell slot.

Name: Hourglass
NOTES: Can be used to track a specific set of time (DM controls length)

Name: Hunting trap
NOTES: When you use your action to set it, this trap forms a saw-toothed steel ring that snaps shut when a creature steps on a pressure plate in the center. The trap is affixed by a heavy chain to an immobile object, such as a tree or a spike driven into the ground. A creature that steps on the plate must succeed on a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw or take 1d4 piercing damage and stop moving. Thereafter, until the creature breaks free of the trap, its movement is limited by the length of the chain (typically 3 feet long). A creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check, freeing itself or another creature within its reach on a success. Each failed check deals 1 piercing damage to the trapped creature.

Name: Ink (1 ounce bottle)
NOTES: Needed to write

Name: Ink pen
NOTES: Needed to write

Name: Iron Pot
NOTES: 1 gallon liquid

Name: Iron Spike
NOTES: Small piece of hard metal

Name: Iron Spikes (10)
NOTES: Bag of Spikes

Name: Jug
NOTES: 1 gallon liquid

Name: Ladder (10-foot)
NOTES: Its a Ladder

Name: Ladder (1-foot)
NOTES: Its a Ladder

Name: Lamp
NOTES: A lamp casts bright light in a 15-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

Name: Lantern- bullseye
NOTES: A bullseye lantern casts bright light in a 60-foot cone and dim light for an additional 60 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil.

Name: Lanture - Hooded
NOTES: A hooded lantern casts bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil. As an action, you can lower the hood, reducing the light to dim light in a 5-foot radius.

Name: Lock
NOTES: A key is provided with the lock. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick this lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Your DM may decide that better locks are available for higher prices.

Name: Magnifying Glass
NOTES: This lens allows a closer look at small objects. It is also useful as a substitute for flint and steel when starting fires. Lighting a fire with a magnifying glass requires light as bright as sunlight to focus, tinder to ignite, and about 5 minutes for the fire to ignite. A magnifying glass grants advantage on any ability check made to appraise or inspect an item that is small or highly detailed.

Name: Manacles
NOTES: These metal restraints can bind a Small or Medium creature. Escaping the manacles requires a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. Breaking them requires a successful DC 20 Strength check. Each set of manacles comes with one key. Without the key, a creature proficient with thieves' tools can pick the manacles' lock with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check. Manacles have 15 hit points.

Name: Merchants's Scale
NOTES: A scale includes a small balance, pans, and a suitable assortment of weights up to 2 pounds. With it, you can measure the exact weight of small objects, such as raw precious metals or trade goods, to help determine their worth.

Name: Mess Kit
NOTES: This tin box contains a cup and simple cutlery. The box clamps together, and one side can be used as a cooking pan and the other as a plate or shallow bowl.

Name: Miner's Pick
NOTES: A pick that can be used to break up other objects.

Name: Mirror - Steel
NOTES: A steel backed Mirror

Name: Monster Hunter's Pack
NOTES: Includes a chest, a crowbar, a hammer, 3 wooden stakes, a holy symbol, a flask of holy water, a set of manacles, a silver mirror, a flask of oil, a tinderbox, and 3 torches.

Name: Oil (flask)
NOTES: Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

Name: Orb - Arcane Focus
NOTES: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Paper (one sheet)
NOTES: A regular piece of paper

Name: Parchment (one sheet)
NOTES: A regular piece of parchment

Name: perfume (vial)
NOTES: A vial that make you smell different than you usually do.

Name: Pitcher
NOTES: 1 gallon liquid

Name: Piton
NOTES: Used to get a liquid out of a wooden object.

Name: Pole (1 foot)
NOTES: Its a stick

Name: Pole (10 foot)
NOTES: Its a long stick

Name: Portable Ram
NOTES: You can use a portable ram to break down doors. When doing so, you gain a +4 bonus on the Strength check. One other character can help you use the ram, giving you advantage on this check.

Name: Potion of Healing
NOTES: A character who drinks the magical red fluid in this vial regains 2d4 + 2 hit points. Drinking or administering a potion takes an action.

Name: Pouch
NOTES: A cloth or leather pouch can hold up to 20 sling bullets or 50 blowgun needles, among other things. A compartmentalized pouch for holding spell components is called a component pouch (described earlier in this section). 1/5 cubic foot/6 pounds of gear

Name: Priest's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a blanket, 10 candles, a tinderbox, an alms box, 2 blocks of incense, a censer, vestments, 2 days of rations, and a waterskin.

Name: Quiver
NOTES: A quiver can hold up to 20 arrows.

Name: Rations (1 day)
NOTES: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

Name: Reliquary - Holy Symbol
NOTES: A holy symbol is a representation of a god or pantheon. Appendix B lists the symbols commonly associated with many gods in the multiverse. A cleric or paladin can use a holy symbol as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10. To use the symbol in this way, the caster must hold it in hand, wear it visibly, or bear it on a shield.

Name: Robes
NOTES: It can be used to cover oneself.

Name: Rod - Arcane Focus
NOTES: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Sack
NOTES: 1 cubic foot/30 pounds of gear

Name: Scholar's Pack
NOTES: Includes a backpack, a book of lore, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, 10 sheets of parchment, a little bag of sand, and a small knife.

Name: Sealing Wax
NOTES: This is typically used to seal letters.

Name: Shield
NOTES: This is an ordinary piece of equipment.

Name: Shovel
NOTES: Can be used to dig dirt.

Name: Signal whistle
NOTES: A loud whistle

Name: Signet ring
NOTES: A ordinary ring.

Name: Silk Rope (1 Foot)
NOTES: Rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Silk Rope (50 feet)
NOTES: Rope has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

Name: Sling bullet
NOTES: Needed to use a sling

Name: Sling bullets (20)
NOTES: Bag of bullets

Name: Soap
NOTES: Used to clean the body.

Name: Spellbook
NOTES: Essential for wizards, a spellbook is a leather-bound tome with 100 blank vellum pages suitable for recording spells.

Name: Sprig of mistletoe - Druidic Focus
NOTES: A druid can use such an object as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Spyglass
NOTES: Objects viewed through a spyglass are magnified to twice their size.

Name: Staff - Arcane Focus
NOTES: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Tankard
NOTES: 1 pint liquid

Name: Tinderbox
NOTES: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch—or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel—takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

Name: Torch
NOTES: A torch burns for 1 hour, providing bright light in a 20-foot radius and dim light for an additional 20 feet. If you make a melee attack with a burning torch and hit, it deals 1 fire damage.

Name: Totem - Druidic Focus
NOTES: A druid can use such an object as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Traveler's Clothes
NOTES: Clothes made spicifically for going long distances.

Name: Two-person Tent
NOTES: A simple and portable canvas shelter, a tent sleeps two.

Name: Vial
NOTES: 4 ounces liquid

Name: Wand - Arcane Focus
NOTES: An arcane focus is a special item designed to channel the power of arcane spells. A sorcerer, warlock, or wizard can use such an item as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Waterskin
NOTES: Can hold upto 4 pints of water. (1 pint = 1 lbs)

Name: Whetstone
NOTES: Used to sharpen metal weapons. Must have water to use effectively. (DM ruling)

Name: Wooden Staff - Druidic Focus
NOTES: A druid can use such an object as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.

Name: Yew wand - Druidic Focus
NOTES: A druid can use such an object as a spellcasting focus, as described in chapter 10.
